author: KHRIS

title: MendelMax Aluminum Plate Y-carriage Bed nut holder

description.text:
I have a simple aluminum plate as my Y-carriage, with 3 bolts holding the bed in place with springs. Leveling the bed is clumsy because you'd have to get a wrench underneath the carriage in order to keep the nut from spinning while you turn the bolt from above.  
I designed this "Nut holder" to capture the nut on the plate so you don't have to use a wrench when leveling the bed. You just adjust it from above with an allen wrench. It also has an integrated "pocket" for the spring.  
Another advantage is the hole for the bolt is tight so it holds the bolt more squarely to the plate, resulting in a more stable bed platform during printing.  
Once printing, you have to mark and drill mounting holes to and bolt them to the plate.

print_settings.Notes:: AM besten mit Reflektoröffnung nach unten offen drucken, dann ist auch der Effekt durch die symetrischen rillen nacher besser.

description.text:
Frontlichter für den Sandmaster 1:10 Buggy.
Am besten das Model mit den Reflektoren nach unten offen platzieren zum drucken.
Was Ihr noch benötigt 2 LEDs 5mm (und evtl. entsprechende widerstände), Chrome Spray (evtl. Acryl Spray), Sandpapier, Kabel, Buchse/Stecker.
Nach dem Druck die inneren Fächen der Refelktoren glatt schleifen, das braucht nicht perfekt glatt sein. Bis auf die Reflektoren alles etwas abkleben und dann als erstes mit dem Acryllack eine oder zwei schichten raufspühen und warten bis es trocken ist, sonst gibt es probleme mit dem Chrome lack der dann als nächstes in die Reflektoren kommt. Wer kein Acryl hat der macht 2 Schichten vom Chromlack, wenn ihm die erste nicht schon reicht. Danach evtl. mit einem 5mm Bohrer die Fassungen für die LEDs vorsichtig nachbohren bis die LED fest sitzt.
Danach Elektronik nach belieben zusammenbauen. Ich habe 2 blaue LEDs genommen. Die Kabel lassen sich durch die röhren zur mitte durchziehen und den Stecker/Buchse, je nachdem was Ihr braucht, jetzt befestigen..
jetzt kann man die LEDs mit einem einzelligen LIPO (3,7 V) direkt betreiben oder sie mit einem Schalterbaustein an einen freien Kanal am Empfänger anschliessen. Ich habe noch jeweils einen 56 Ohm widerstand vor die LEDs gelötet.
Für die Kappen habe ich noch jeweils ein stück durchsichtiges Plastik zurechtgschnitten.

Die Löcher für die Befestigung habe ich nicht mit in das Modell genommen, die muss jeder noch selber einpassen. Durchmesser 3mm, abstand mittelpunkt 12 mm bei dem Sandmaster. Andere Modell muss jeder selber ausmessen wenn es dann passt.

Hoffe das gefällt und demnächst fahren ein paar Sandmaster beleuchtet durch die gegend, schickt eure fotos

description.text:
Jack yourself up!

This is a customizable screw jack. Screw jacks are useful for setting up and supporting large awkward parts.

This screw jack has two options for the screw jack top. Option 1) a fixed screw jack top for supporting flat components. Option 2) The screw jack top has a ball swivel to support uneven components.

The current parts show are designed for a 5/16-18 threaded rod and nut.

Press nut into the top of the screw jack base. Add an adhesive to secure the nut in place Cut a piece of threaded rod to size. Use Loctite to secure a nut to the threaded rod Press the threaded rod nut into the jact top. Again, use adhesive to fix the nut to the jack top
Screw jack with swivel jack top Screw Jack with fixed jack top

description.text:
This is remixed from Note-Generator. I refactored code and turned it into a bracelet (by the same way of Generalized zentangle bracelet).

Notes may be customized. See Instructions of Note-Generator for how to input notes.

For example, the STL example here is the beginning of the song "You are my sunshine", created from the following notestring:

  • 4:br,4:g1,4:c2,4:d2,bar,2:e2,2:e2,bar,4:br,4:e2,#:d2,4:d2,4:e2,bar,2:c2,2:c2

The height parameter means the height of the area containing notes so a higher height makes notes bigger. A higher radius may contains more notes.

You may use the Preview mode to check whether the notes are right for you..

  • OpenSCAD Documentation - Traditional Chinese
  • OpenSCAD Documentation - English

standard

Notes:

This project challenge was to leverage 3D printing to replace the lost piece(s) of a game.

This is a follow-up to a hackathon we did a year ago https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IaEsNvijt8k (:30) where Matthew was originally exposed to 3D printing and we could not find self-guided instructions for 3D printing.

Twitter: @printpiece
To encourage engagement the project was also documented on instagram: https://www.instagram.com/pieceprint/

TinkerCAD Creation

I designed this simple pawn piece with TinkerCAD by dragging and dropping various dimensional objects such as cylinders, cones, spheres, etc. and overlapping them to create a chess piece.

Pawn Replacement

By completing this project, you will have learned how to replace a lost pawn so you can keep playing with your chess board.

Download Instructions: https://cdn.thingiverse.com/assets/64/d2/ff/95/4d/Replacement_Pawnfinal.pdf

First, open Tinkercad and start to design your pawn with the various three-dimensional objects located on the side of the screen.

Next, press Design-Download for 3D Printing and wait for it to download. Select “.stl”.

When you finish the download and open the file in the MakerBot software, prepare the “.stl” file for printing.

Lastly, connect to a 3D printer or export your file to a flash drive and print your new 3D pawn.

description.text:
Printrbot Simple Filament Spool Holder/Coaster.

I couldn't find a Filament Holder I liked for my Printrbot Simple Metal, I designed one over a year ago, but it was too complicated, it used screws and bearings and still had issues. This one is simple, print in one run and your done! Plus it works great, you can leave your printer unattended and not worry about the spool jamming or falling off. Here are some of the highlights:

-Sits on top of printer saving desk space.
-All Spools sizes: Supports spools up to 95 mm wide and around 200 mm in diameter, I haven't seen any bigger spools, but if you need wider let me know, I can make an extension.
-Can leave printer unattended, I've tested with cardboard and plastic spools, they rotate easy (make sure you make your filament feed from the bottom like my pictures, it puts less stress on motor).
-Allow printer full Z access motion (up to 150mm) on all the spools I've tried.

**If your interested in mounting it on a table, let me know in the comments section, I can design a Table mount so you can use this with any printer.

Hope you like it, and give me feedback to improve it!!

Tim

title: WANHAO Duplicator i3 - Z-Axis Alignment Block with Magnet feature

description.text:
This is my personal version of the Z-Axis Alignment Block for the WANHAO Duplicator i3. It could be use for other printers but I designed it with the WDi3. The cavity at the base is to place a .750" dia x .375" thick magnet to ease the alignment process. In order to make sure both Z-Axis motors are aligned at the same height, I'm not recommending printing two of those to align both side at the same time. Getting two CNC machined parts at the exact same size is hard, so getting two 3D printed parts at the exact same dimensions is even harder.

The little hole is just to help you get the magnet out of the alignment block.

comments.text:
My son printed your enclosure for my Red Pitaya with his Prusa I3 MK2S, using ABS.
To my astonishment, the casing didn't fit. The width was OK, but it was a millimeter too short.
No great harm done, a bit of filing on the back (power, USB & ethernet side), and everything fits.
comments.author: ghp

description.text: I had a hole in my wall due to an old open unused electric outlet. now i dont

Use this battery-shaped box to build a battery eliminator and power your camera from a DC power supply instead of having to replace batteries. Very useful for studio work and astrophotography.

The size matches NB-2LH, which is used in Canon Rebel (350D) and probably other Canon cameras (see the third picture). Size: 45 x 33.5 x 16 mm (1.77 x 1.31 x 0.63 in).

The three terminals are (-), (T), and (+). Pass a metal strip through the slots to make terminal contact pads and connect a 7.4V power supply to (-) and (+). Place a 10K resistor between (-) and (T).

I'd recommend attaching a piece of string to the round pin to make it easier to pull this contraption out of your camera.

I was using a chain I had purchased from Amazon and I ended up needing more links so I modeled these links to be compatible with the one I had bought. I liked how it turned out so much I will be using this 100% instead of mixing it with my purchased chain.

I will include the STEP file if you would like to change it in any way. I will add mount links when I have some time to model them.

I made this to mount a quad bike starter solenoid on my lowboy quad para-glider.
The solenoid is 34mm diameter and mounted to a 25mm tube.

Printed in PETG. Long m3 screws hold the 3 parts together. Knurl nuts were used.
I added a freewheeling diode across the coil - optional but might increase starter button life.
The coil connection use M3 screws. currently plain nuts with spring washers but I have M3 lock nuts on order.
Print these cheap sticks to mix epoxy components. Throw away after use!

author: Bearau

title: Horny Tucano - TPU Pod for Camdrones Twister 210

description.text:
This is a TPU Pod for the Camdrones Twister 210 available at http://www.campilot.at.

I've eyeballed it for a naze. I personally designed it for me for a Graupner GR-18 which is not as wide.

It snap fits a HS 1177, Runcam Swift, TBS ZeroZero ( one at a time ).
VTX must have a pigtail and is intented to be put above the fc. The Antenna socket is directly behind the camera. The horn should be used to zip tie the vtx antenna to it. with the large holes in the rear you can press channel select buttons.

the naze's usb connector should be put at 15mm height above the baseplate to be able to use the usb hole on the right.

I've printed it with support, 10 lines brim, .2mm resolution, 50% infill from sainsmart tpu. 215deg extruder, 70deg heatbed
i've used autodesk fusion 360 for it. a great tool and free for personal use.

author: jason51873

description.text:
I printed these to make it easier to carry my Robo 3D printers. I transport the printers twice a week to two different schools and it was hard to carry them and open doors at the same time; these help a lot. Just put the handle parts into the slot at the top of the printer and turn them 90 degrees to nest them together and it's ready to carry.
Printed with ABS, 100% fill.

5-25-2016
Added dovetail handle files.

comments.text: This is so helpful for transporting! I will definitely be using this thing. Can I use PLA for it and does it have to be 100% infill?
comments.author: Nelson15324

comments.text:
Thanks!
I don't see any reason why it would not work with PLA. And I would think it would work fine printed at less than 100% fill if you have a good solid shell (e.g., 30% fill with 5 or 6 vertical shells and 6 or 7 horizontal shells at a .3mm per layer setting). This should give about a 2mm solid shell around a 30% fill core. I'm just guessing on strength as I have not tested one to find out how much it can hold before it breaks. Yet.

author: hemanth

description.text:
Mounting clips for holding my clear cases on our Robo 3D printers.
I bring the printers to schools and these cases keep fingers out of the moving, hot printers and keeps cold air off the prints while allowing for great viewing. The clear cases are very easy to lift on and off.
The "Part A" is glued to the Robo 3D case and the "Part B" is glued to the clear plastic case.
Printed with 100% fill using ABS.

6-8-2016 Added corner reinforcement pieces and some information about the clear acrylic cases. So far I've made 4 of these cases; two for each printer. I cut the parts from three 18" x 24" sheets of 1.9mm thick acrylic which I got at Lowe's for about $10 each. I used a table saw for the straight cuts, and a scroll saw for the curves on the two side pieces.
Each case is 5 pieces:
2pc. - Sides = 280mm X 259.9mm
1pc. - Top = 258mm X 283mm
1pc. - Back = 280mm X 283mm
1pc. - Bottom = 170mm X 283mm

title: B9 Environmental Control Robot (Lost in Space)

description.text:
robot from lost in space (LIS).
Ok,,, Long story here.
At Maker Faire NY I met Mike Joyce who makes the B9 creator
resin 3D printer. When he saw my display He asked why i had not
made the robot from lost in space. I made a unflattering remark
about the b9robot from LIS. Mike informed me he is the
distributor/builder of the only full sized licensed b9 robot.
So,, I had to make a b9 robot (as my way of apologizing) intended for resin printing.
hopefully this is a adequate model. second version b9robot3PE3R.stl has the shoulder loops,
power pack and a different knob on the torso, somewhat closer
to the original.

intended for resin printer, not sure FDM/FFF will do well
with the finer details (antenna) and overhangs second version b9robot3PE3R.stl has the shoulder loops,
power pack and a different knob on the torso, somewhat closer
to the original.

the bubble would be a bit rough on the underside. and it might be a delicate cleanup.
i might split it for FDM supportless printing (like dutchmogul does on lots of his models).
I actually modeled the claws closed so it could possibly be FDM printed and cleaned up with
a jewlers saw.
Have a nice trip back to GB!

remixed_from.title: X axis belt tensioner with bearings for the Da Vinci 3D printer

title: X Axis Belt Tensioner with Bearings

description.text:
I took the original model, trimmed down the bits that slide in the grooves in the frame so it slides in freely, but at the same time thickened the front so there's actually more material for the idler pulley to rest against. I also removed a few unneeded curves and the plates around the spring so it doesn't have any supports that are a pain to remove.

Printed at 100% infill with slic3r's automatic supports. I used PLA and it seems to be fine because it just doesn't get hot enough to matter, but only time will tell if it warps.

You do need two MR63ZZ bearings. Easily found on Amazon.

description.text: median strip road

title: BD's Tarantula X-Axis Motor and Idler Mounts

description.text:
These mounts are for the x-axis motor and idler pulley mounts for the Tevo Tarantula 3D printer. These can be used in conjunction with the Tarantula's stock z-axis carriages or with custom z-axis carriages that do not incorporate mounts for the x-axis motor and pulleys.

There are two versions of the motor mount. One incorporates a lower appendage that can be used as an adjustable trigger for a z-min end stop. There is a place to embed a M3 lock nut in the bottom, and then you would use a long M3 screw to engage the z-min end stop.

If you are installing these with the Tarantula's stock z-axis carriages in place you will need 30mm M3 screws for the motor mount and 30mm M5 screws (or longer) for the idler pulleys. You may also want/need to make sure these brackets are fully seated on the aluminum extrusion -- you may need to adjust your z-carriages or drill new holes in the acrylic if the holes don't line up perfectly for your particular build.

UPDATE 2016/05/25

I have added three new STLfiles that are for Rev2 of the idler pulley mount. This design incorporates a tensioner into the mount. To use this with the stock z-carriage on the idler side you will need two low profile M5 screws and two M5 locknuts for the pulley axles, and you will need one hex head M5 x 30mm screw, 1 or 2 M5 washers, a standard M5 hex nut and some light duty thread locker (e.g. LocTite Blue) for the tensioner mechanism.

Video of my dry run of this new design: https://youtu.be/UyyxU8uNeCY

title: Two Tone Gen4 Buttons
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Replacement buttons for the Gen 4 LCD Interface. No Dual Extrusion needed ! To print in 2 colors, use the new "Automatic Pause at Z Position" feature, which will allow you to pause during printing at the appropriate point and change filament. This feature can be found in the new Gen 4 firmware: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:15380

• Decide if you want recessed or raised buttons and download the appropriate .stl.

  • Print using Print-O-Matic settings, 100% fill, 0 shells and raft (support = none).

  • After the raft has completed and it's started printing the first real layer note the Z Position, on my printer it's 1.41mm. Now add 5.7mm (the height to the start of the text) = 7.11mm, and hit the cancel button. Choose Pause At ZPos and enter 7.11mm.

  • When printing automatically pauses, use the X/Y/Z Jog to move the build away from the platform, then use Rev/Fwd to change your filament color. Then hit cancel to finish the print.
    • If altering the design with OpenScad. Be aware that the text derivative: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6844 has issues with backslashes that stop compilation. So you will need 6844Fixed.zip and TTG4Buttons.scad.

print_settings.Notes:: Printed with ABS. If you do not print a solid part (100% infill) you may want to consider at least 2 mm solid top and bottom layer and thich shells to slow down the wear.

description.text:
Repair part for the wire spool of a Stiga SB40 Brush Cutter / Grass Trimmer. The original is made of plastic and eventually the surface is grinded to almost nothing and it falls out, or has just disappeared. When that happens you will have a large hole in the head that scoops up dirt rather than press the internal spring to release more thread.

I had to either buy a comple new head or repair the spool holder. Guess what, I did the latter using my home built reprap.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.5 mm nozzle, 0.2 mm layer height

Infill:

35%

Notes:

Printed with ABS. If you do not print a solid part (100% infill) you may want to consider at least 2 mm solid top and bottom layer and thich shells to slow down the wear.

Assembly

Disassemble the trimmer head and take out the spool holder. Wipe away any dirt or dust.

Cut out the sprocket-like center of the spool holder (if it has not already fallen out) and nicely cut away the remnants such that you get a clean sprocket-like hole.

Print the replacement part and check if it fits by placing it upside down in the hole that you previously prepared. If required adjust any of the two parts with a stanley knife.

When you are happy with the form fit, and it may well be a bit tight, insert the replacement part in de bottom. Make sure it is positioned well enough to go all the way down and come out at the end: It will be hard to rotate once inside. Use a vice to press the replacement part all the way through until it comes out at the end.

Assemble your spool holder and you're done.

FreeCAD

The shape is a pretty straighforward. With the help of some online FreeCAD tutorials I was able to create the shape I wanted within 20 min. Just some tweaking and a few trial prints were left before the design fit my needs.

description.text:
This is a case for the M12864, which is a variant based on the quite wonderful universal transistor and component tester developed by Markus Frejek, and later Karl-Heinz Kübbeler. A full description of the project is available here:

http://mikrocontroller.net/articles/AVR_Transistortester

This case fits the variant with graphical display and rotary knob sold by Banggood and probably elsewhere called M12864. The case includes a compartment for the battery. The pinout for the 14 pin ZIF test socket is printed on the case, for reference. Note that there are several different variants of this tester in the market. This case is only designed to fit the M12864.

You need four M3x15 (or thereabouts) countersunk screws for assembling the top and bottom sections. It works best if you thread first using an M3 tap.

When assembling, note routing of the battery wire in the picture. This is crucial to make sure the wire does not get kinched.

The knob is a friction fit, so the dimensions are critical. In my configuration a 5.6 mm inner diameter was good, but you may find that you may need a slightly smaller or larger diameter. This can easily be done in the Configurator.

Please examine the pictures of the PCB carefully to make sure you have the right PCB before you start your print. Cases for other variants are available here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:797733 here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:694790 and here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1920077

Printer:

Bukobot

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

Should print without support, and with not too much cleanup. If warping is an issue, you may consider adding a brim. The top section should be printed upside-down.

title: Printrbot Plus V1 offset Z-axis nut: less wobble

description.text: Remix of Tom_Maragos's http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:104733 to fit my V1 Printrbot Plus. The OpenSCAD file takes the original STL, closes the hex nut and threaded rod hole, creates new centered rod and hex holes (joined with a conical section to avoid bridges during printing. This is set up for a M8x1.25 metric rod and nut, but the OpenSCAD file could be easily changed for any size. The original file has differing left and right units. I used the same unit for both sides, but had to trim a tiny bit off the left unit with an x-acto to accommodate the z-axis end stop holder. It's tight on purpose and needed a little trimming to fit the z nut. This is good, should eliminate all but the nut/rod backlash.

title: Penny Shooter

description.text: This is a business card that shoots US pennies. It has a little magazine that pops up and allows you to load up to 10 pennies. Then you can just pull back the slide and release to shoot a penny, and repeat until all the pennies are gone. A video of the card in action - http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5KNZZ9qDJtQ

Cut the thick parts from a material that is approximately the thickness of a penny (0.061\"). A good 4 ply mat board should be close to .06\". If the material is too thick or thin then the pennies will jam, but I am not sure of the tolerance limits. The thin material should be strong enough to give good support, but thin enough to handle the folds for the magazine. I use a .014\" thick cover stock. The dotted lines on the magazine area of the thin components should be a perforation or a crease. 
The thick components get sandwiched between the two thin layers. Start by gluing the two identical thick pieces to the thin side without the magazine. Use the other thick piece (the slide) as a guide and make sure it can slide easily between the parts and close flush. Then glue the side with the magazine on top. Take care not to glue the magazine down and make sure the slide can still move back and forth. The slide must be in place before you glue it together because it can not be installed after the rest of the card is assembled. Two #32 rubber bands are needed to use the card.

print_settings.Notes:: In-Vehicle Handset mount:

description.text:
Intro:

Hello and thanks for checking out my design.

This was a solution I designed when going off-road and having to use the Motorola GP-388PLUS radio. I needed a place to mount it in the vehicle. Cupholders & Co-Pilot are the common solutions and drilling holes wasn't an option. I used 3M double sided adhesive instead, easy to remove with adhesive removal.

This was specifically designed for my radio type, but this should work for most portable UHF radios that have a belt clip and a handset.

Let me know in the comments if theres a specific mount you'd require.

Description:

Radio Handset Clip:
This circular clip was printed at 1mm for tolerance purposes, but will work with 2mm.
It is designed to seat itself in the existing hole on the handset and the washer-nut combo mounted on the back of the metal clip clamps down the clip. It uses a M3 nut and bolt to mount it all together.

Radio Unit Mount:
This is designed to utilise the existing Motorola GP388Plus belt clip. A gap at the bottom of the holster allows the clip to engage and therefore seat snug and won't fall out incase of rollover or extreme terrain.

In-Vehicle Handset mount:
This is a simple handset mounting configuration that cradles the Radio Handset clip you've printed. It has a .5mm tolerance on each side which can be widened with a file for a more loose fit. I wanted it to be a snug fit so the handset would stay in place.

A little sanding/filing require for cleanup

Happy Printing!

title: It Doesn't Have to Look Like Raspberry Pi Zero Case

description.text:
Update: RPi_Zero_Case_v4b1.stl is Pi inverted! The Pi Zero goes in with the camera connector pointing down and the Micro SD Card pointing up. This puts the power plug on the side near the bottom instead of the top.

So I FINALLY got a Raspberry Pi Zero - just after they announced the new model with the camera connector - ugh...

Anywho. I thought I'd design a nice case for it that would look kinda stylish sitting on the desk, and not obviously yarpic (yet-another-raspberry-pi-case). Jury is out if I achieved that or not.

I thought Translucent Red would look nice, but now I think it looks yucky. Sorry. "Gold" was the other color I had handy.

Single piece. Slide the Pi in from the top. No supports needed.

You can slide the MicroSD card in and out from the bottom and there should be enough room at the top for a Pi Zero with Camera Connector as well. I'm thinking the tower/chimney effect should help with cooling.

I think a CPU heat sink will fit inside, but haven't tried it.

Yes, it took me 4.a tries to get a case I liked that fit/looks good...

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

15% or 100%

Notes:

Doesn't need support. The spans can be crossed just fine with a medium good printer.
You can do either 15% or 100% infill - it makes less than a meter difference in filament.
I do recommend rafting as the base is very thin and you'd hate for it to come off mid-print.

Nasty Little Hairs

You'll probably get nasty little hairs inside unless you have one of those really nice printers and slicers. So clean them out with a small file before inserting your Pi. It will be a snug fit, but will loosen with use.

How I did it - by Victor Von Frankenstein

I used Sketchup...because I'm a masochist.
The compound curves were a PITA.

description.text:
Update June 2017
All files containing V2 are the updated files. The original files will be left.

Updates

  • Added inserts for M3 nuts into the motor mount and battery trays. (No more screwing directly into the 3d printed parts
  • Added a brace to go over the servo (No drilling holes in the chassis).
  • Improved clearance for the radio & antenna.

The assembly instructions are for the most part the same. The lower battery plate gets mounted, then the upper battery plate needs to be glued to the lower. Then the Servo cover can be aligned and glued in place. There is no need to drill holes in the chassis.

End Update

This is a brushless conversion kit for the Traxxas Jato.

The battery box is 43mm * 135mm. I used two of these batteries in parallel: http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__11949__Turnigy_nano_tech_3300mah_3S_35_70C_Lipo_Pack.html

The RX box is 32mm * 49mm.

There is a significant amount of post processing and assembly required before these parts can be mounted in the truck.

Printer:

Ultibots Kossel

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.3

Infill:

100%

Notes:

The BatteryPlate_Top should not be printed with supports. Everything else requires them.

Step 1 - Prepare the print

There are a few areas that will need to be sanded/filed to fit you specific equipment

  1. The motor mount - check clearance for your motor shaft, pinion, and slipper clutch backing plate.
  2. The receiver cover/hatch - Check the tab fitment into the battery tray. This is a little fragile, so be careful when sanding.
  3. The pin for the receiver cover - once the cover fits nicely, the pin will need to be drilled to fit your body clips. This is easiest when the battery plate is not attached to the car.
  4. The battery tray, on the outboard servo mount holes. The bottom of the chassis angles up here. You will need to sand this tab to match the angle on the chassis.
Step 2 - Prepare the Jato

Remove everything from the front bulkhead back. You will need to install a single speed conversion. I recommend the steel gears from Hot Racing - http://www.hot-racing.com/index.cgi?partnumber=SJT1000SS;c=180

You will also need to remove the edge guards. They will not fit with this battery tray without significant modification.

Clean/remove the foam under the original RX battery box.

You need to drill at least one hole into the chassis to support the front of the battery tray near the servos. There are two holes, but the outboard hole is at an angle, which makes drilling the hole difficult. I have not had any problem only using the one inboard screw.

Step 3 - Glue the parts together
  1. Test fit the bottom plate onto the chassis using a couple of screws from the side guards.
  2. Check the top plate fitment & mark it's position.
  3. Remove the bottom plate and glue the pieces together. I used Aceton and clamped the pieces together.
  4. You need to drill holes through the top plate, using the holes in the bottom plate as guides. I used a 3/32 drill bit.
  5. Once the glue has dried, you will need to feed in your battery straps. The slot that is adjacent to the RX cover is difficult. I found it easiest to drill a small hole down from the top of the slot, through both plates. Then I used a pin/drill bit through that hole to work the strap around the corner.
Step 4 - Assemble the truck
  1. Mount all electronics into the battery plate. The ESC uses double sided tape, and there is a slot in the tray to fit a zip tie if needed. There are holes/channels for all of the servo wires to be hidden.
  2. Mount the motor to the motor mount, then install the motor mount in the truck. There are two bolts that go into the transmission, and one bolt that goes through the chassis plate.
  3. Mount the battery plate to the chassis. Do not over tighten the bolts into the 3d printed parts. They will strip.

Some of the screws can be re-used from removed parts. I bought a screw kit off ebay just to have extras.

For the battery plate you will need to use 3 of the screws for the side guards. They are 3*8 countersunk screws. You need to ensure whatever screws you use are not long enough to poke into the battery backs.

The two holes near the steering servo and in the motor mount bottom also need 3mm countersunk screws. I used 10-12mm length screws.

This is a holder for solar filter film for binoculars. The idea is to be able to quickly install the solar filter so as to look at the sun for sunspots and planetary transits, and then quickly remove it when done with the sun.

The solar filter film itself can be bought online, then cut so as to completely cover the printed holder hole. The ring presses the filter in place, and the covers (two per holder) allow you to store it all nicely.

I have added the scad file so that the print can be modified within reason.

Make sure that the printed holders fit snuggly onto your binocular tubes. You don't want them to come off while you are looking at the sun. Also, make sure that both tubes are covered and avoid looking at the sun without both filters snuggly fit.

Snug fits

All the printed parts should fit snuggly, so that no glue should be necessary. If the fit is loose then use glue or modify the dimensions as necessary.

author: fsmith

description.text:
Replacement pool jet for swimming pool.
Threads are modeled using the National standard taper pipe threads chart but modified for better printing and application needs. IE its not meant to make a watertight seal.

The pool jets available in my local pool store have a 1.5"NPT to 2" threaded body with a 2" cap. This design is meant to eliminate the cap and keep a low (slim diameter) profile to accommodate the lack of clearance in our pool.

comments.text: I used your threads in two of my designs, but didn't list them as a remix as they serve different purposes. You are credited for the threads, just thought I would let you know. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1605135 http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1617652

This carriage is designed with integrated dual 40mm fans, budaschnozzle, and LM8UU linear bearings.   
The fan bodies are used to hold the LM8UU bearings in place. The LM8UU bearings are left a little bit of float so as not to bind the X-axis and reduce quality.  
The carriage directs the airflow from both fans precisely at the tip of the extruder when a standard budaschnozzle is used.  
The linear bearings are spaced 50mm apart center to center.  
Currently used on my Mendelmax 1.5  
Enjoy.

I printed this using 0.35mm nozzle, 5 perimeters, and 30% infill.

This part holds the wires in the channel of a 20x20 aluminum extrusion. They are small and print quickly so you can print lots of them to keep all those wires organized. You might notice that the corners have little cut-outs. This is something i've adapted from an old typeface technique known as an ink trap. In printing, it is used to keep crisp edges in corners. The technique seems to work well for 3d printing. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ink_trap

use a .35 layer height or smaller in order to get enough infill. or experiment: it's not like you're wasting much plastic for a failed print!
The Stl prints 2 clips at once.
I use these on the Prism mendel.

remixed_from.author: big_red_frog
remixed_from.title: Halo 4 Helmet Full Size ( Adult - 6'6" plus )

remixed_from.author: big_red_frog
remixed_from.title: Halo 4 Helmet Full Size ( Small child )

description.text:
NOT rated for motor vehicle use, general safety equipment or Type 26/42/52 directed energy plasma cannons. To better support detailed instructions and development, now hosting blog like content at hackaday projects which is in alpha, at http://projects.hackaday.com/project/254-Halo-4-Helmet-(-Size-A%2C-B%2C-C-) This model is expected to deprecate the previous versions. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:138405 and
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:127801 and is a derivative from this 3dmax original. http://hce.halomaps.org/index.cfm?fid=6127 This is size A - Adult I now have a size C - small Child at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:181491 And a size B - medium at
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:225884 Proven vac formed visor as per http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:217267 Got featured at Autodesk University and won an award for design in Fusion 360. mulitple shots in this video - Yeah me! http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CZvTiF6rJ3A All components have images of successful print and build time. All modelling in Autodesk Fusion 360, its free for non commercial use, I highly recommend it. Now using Netfabb basic to post process STL for origin, orientation and repair, so thingiview will also now work. STL should be in correct orientation on dropping direct into Makerware! Just move to center of plate, and in some cases rotate to fit the bed nicely. See instructions. Please comment, its been exhausting, so would appreciate the banter. All upgrades, such as led modified back light and perforated visor will be posted as separate "things" See... Chin Front with M4 bolt modifications http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:163439 Perforated Visor for Halo Helmet http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:165110 Added a full version of the visor as it will fit in a Replicator 2. Halo 4 Helmet Size A Big Pieces Combined components where separation was unnecessary if you have a replicator 2 size build volume. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:168678 Halo 4 Helmet Full Size A with tiewraps, working through the pieces and placing mounting holes for tiewraps to aid with wire harness control. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:169295 Halo 4 Helmet Full Size A Peak with Batteries http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:171912 A youtube link from the comments that is too good to miss... http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=adaM1AwloSo A render from keyshot 4 http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QzgpZea5mSk&hd=1 An assembly video kindly created by http://www.thingiverse.com/rmasching https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DUKPIUbehpY&feature=youtu.be Deprecated derivatives. Backlight with LED mount - Now been added directly to this thing, replacing the non LED version. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:161575 Enjoy!

All designed in Autodesk Fusion 360 Note ChinFront_r1_0.stl has been updated to address artifact present in Makerware. Not apparent why, but single slice layer was appearing as just support near top of print. Piece flipped in netfabb and resaved, artifact goes away! All STL sliced with Makerware to x3g at medium profile 0.2mm layers, default settings, 2 shells, 10% infill, with raft and support. Latest Makerware suggests scaling some pieces to fit. DO NOT. All pieces will fit a Replicator 2 print area with simple rotation about the vertical axis and centering. The "down" face should be preserved for best results. Total build time for main body is ~60 hours on my Makerbot Replicator 2 in PLA. Including pins ( no visor or magnets ) is 680 grams, so you can budget one Kilo gram per helmet with raft, support and reprints. Don't forget some natural for your visor / inserts. Its 16 main pieces as per attached files, and 4 inserts / visor. Using the other "things" for combined pieces it comes down to 12 main pieces. You can get it down to 7 main + insert full plates by printing multiple pieces on one replicator 2 bed. All uploaded files have been preprocessed in netfabb basic for integrity and orientation. Generally Magnets used are 3/8 x 1/10 99K32.03 - 19 off http://www.leevalley.com/en/wood/page.aspx?p=32065&cat=1,42363,42348 Placed in 3/8 steel cups 99K32.52 - 15 off http://www.leevalley.com/en/wood/page.aspx?p=32066&cat=1,42363,42348&ap=1 Jowl insert retaining magnets are 1/4" x 1/10" 99K31.01 from same page again. - 4 off http://www.leevalley.com/en/wood/page.aspx?p=32065&cat=1,42363,42348 Tension pins throughout model are 1/8" x 3/4" as per 240-025 - 57 off ( just buy a box of 100 ) http://www.spaenaur.com/pdf/sectionE/E107.pdf Print, glue, pin for alignment during glueing. Magnet for snap attach of peak, chin and visor if desired. Add foam to fit for proper alignment. Use 5mm LED's in all inserts. - 6 off ( presently ) Assembly order is roughly shown at https://hackaday.io/project/254-halo-4-helmet-size-a-b-c/log/31656-assembly-order No grunts were spared in the making of this product. Enjoy. This is a 15% reduction of the 6'6 model. So scaled to 85%. There are many other changes so not all parts can be reversed back into the 6'6 model., however, should you wish to try for parts like the vacform mold, chin piece with detail, or the hex visor, you would scale the A size model pieces by 117.6471%

comments.text: Hey guys, so I printed all the pieces for this helmet using abs and now i want to do a cold vapor finish with it using acetone. If anyone has made this helmet and done a similar finish, I was wondering if you could tell me if it's better to do the cold vapor finish after the helmet is fully assembled or to do the finish piece by piece. My only concern with doing it piece by piece is that the finishing process could warp the inserts for the tension pins and magnets. Any info or recommendations would be greatly appreciated! Thanks!
comments.author: ajh124

comments.text: I'm making another helmet now where I'm sanding bit by bit, and then I'll glue it together and then do the acetone party. You can, however, just mask of the parts you don't want "acetoned" with masking tape or paint or anything really.
comments.author: ajh124

comments.text: I was planning on painting some intricate designs with black paint; something along the lines of hieroglyphics or similar... Would you recommend do this before or after the acetone finish?
comments.author: Martorias

comments.text: If you paint before then the painted parts won't be affected much by the acetone so if you got lines you'll keep them. I'd do the smoothing before any paint myself.
comments.author: ajh124

comments.text: How are you sanding this? I tried sanding a piece with 100, 300, and 600 grit sandpaper and then did an acetone finish. But i didn't like the way it looked/felt compared to only doing an acetone finish.
comments.author: Martorias

comments.text: Yeah the acetone only gives a nice porcelain style, but it won't matter much once you paint on top of it. I'm trying acetone first, then sanding with 240->400, then I'll do a spray filler and then sand that with 400 and then spraypaint/airbrush.

comments.text: I tried a clear pla filament from http://diamondage.co.nzdiamondage.co.nz though the following might apply to other manufacturers as well. When I print only 2 horizontal layers can get very close to transparent if the speed is slow and extruder feed is calibrated correctly. However if I try same 2 layers vertically result is opaque. So if you want a flat visor it might be possible. Probably easier to make a shaped mould with printer then find some old plastic packaging that is heat shapeable at lower temperature and then stretch it over the printed mould. Not elegant solution but should work.

Recently I came across the 8 mm pneumatic tubing with its various valves, quick-fit couplers, etc. They are very cheap and usable for both air and water at substantial pressure.
One of the things I could not find, however, were low-voltage valves (those I found were basaed on 24V solenoids and used some current ALWAYS when turned on. Additionally, they did not allow partial opening, which is not of much importance for me but still not cool.

So what I did was adapting a valve intended for hand usage to servo operation!
I used standard size servos (Futaba S3003 specifically), which operate at 5V, have 0.5A max current draw and are easily controlled by a microprocessor. Plus, when they reach the desired position they go idle, consuming 8mA. Cool? Cool!

1. Install the shaft coupler onto the servo
  2. Unscrew the handle and cut out the walls limiting rotation
  3. Fix the valve in position with zip ties
  4. Insert the servo, check rotation (marks on the shaft coupler will help with determining current position), adjust the coupler position on the servo if necessary, fix in place by M3 screws.

description.text:
Get your Ozobots suited up with customizable HARDWEAR helmet for capturing Ozo-Energy Disks

A universal Ozobot helmet featuring accessory attachment to outfit your Ozobots for mission success!

  • Mission operators, utilize these Ozobot "hardwear" upgrades to help you overcome any obstacles in your path. The supplied Grabber Arm can be used to maneuver energy disks back to your base hanger.

  • Educators, the following thing details include classroom exercise prompts and suggestions to help you expand your Ozobot curriculum with your students.

Imagine, create, and navigate your very own specialized missions for your Ozobots.

Team Members:
David Choi, Meghan Vellotti, & Michael Parker

These Ozobot helmets are an expansion to Michael Parker's classroom exercise for 3D printing with Ozobots at Dimension Learning based in NYC.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.20 mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Supports Needed:

  • "Ozo_Universal_Helmet.stl"
  • "Ozo_Grabber_Arm.stl"
  • "Ozo_Home_Base_Hanger.stl"

Rafts Needed:

  • "Ozo_Grabber_Claws.stl"
  • Recommend to use supports for other files as necessary (especially those that require supports)

Shells:

  • We printed using 3 shells (1.2 mm walls with a 0.4 mm nozzle) for strength

Tools Needed & Asssembly

For these prints, due to their small scale and mechanical parts, we opted to use 1.75mm diameter filament as shafts and pegs for assembly.

Use pliers to pinch the ends of the filament once it is installed. This will hold it in place.

The Ozobot Helmet is a modular design and can accommodate custom grabbers or other accessories. Provided is the file "Ozo_Universal_Accessory_Attachment_Mount.stl" which can be added to a custom design in order to fit the Ozobot helmet attachment.

It is recommended to use thin bead file or hobby knife to clear away any excess print material from the filament mounting holes in the prints!

1.75mm filament to hold parts together. Use pliers to pinch and capture the ends in place as shown in the picture above. Capturing the Ozobot Profile

The Ozobot is mostly round but that "mostly" part makes it difficult to create nice dimension diagrams. We used a top view photograph of an Ozobot to replicate the finer details of its profile to make a proper-fitting helmet.

Vectorizing the profile of Ozobot's top view image... Adding circles and curves to match the details... Clean up and rescaling to actual size Adding mechanical tolerance offsets and an outer profile for the helmet prior to extruding in CAD Iterations of test fitting. Pink = Lower profile test, Yellow = Upper profile test, White = Weight reduction test, Blue = Final The Base Hanger

The base hangers come directly from our Ozobot dystopian future. It was modeled with simple rectangles then fed through nTopology Element's advanced freeware algorithms.

Original hanger file prior to processing Quickly generating a wireframe lattice Thickening up the lattice structures

Students in teams will create an Ozobot game, with their own mission board and own rules. They will need to program Ozobots to succeed in their respective missions, as well as 3D print Ozobot "hardwear" for the game. Ozobots will need to maneuver an obstacle course in order to get an energy disk back to their hanger, while the defending Ozobot team will attempt to hamper all efforts by any means necessary. Students have the option to design and 3d print custom grabber arms or shields for the Ozobot using a 3D design program such as Sketchup, 123D, or Morphi. The key focus is to strategically pre-program the Ozobot to navigate the game field in order to win. Objectives
Teamwork & Collaborative Design
3D CAD Design
3D Printing
Mechanical Engineering
Computer Programming
Game Design

Sample Game Break students up into teams of three or four (make sure you have an even number of teams).
Have each team come up with a team name.
Randomly pair up teams (for instance, team 1 and team 4 are a pair, etc.)
Have each pair of teams design their mission board together (mission board not be bigger than 1’ x 2’). A feasible strategy would be to draw lines on the mission board that the offending team’s Ozobot cannot cross (or they lose points). Example mission board shown below (blue lines cannot be crossed by offending team). Each pair of teams should also come up with rules for the game (or they can use the Game Rules listed below).
Have students design a helmet attachment for the Ozobot on a 3D design program such as Sketchup or Tinkercad. They can use the sample files provided, or create their own, depending on their skill level. Students will then 3D print these designs.
Students will write programs for the Ozobot in Blockly to both defend the hanger and attempt to deposit energy disks in the hanger.
Once all teams are finished, teams will compete in a tournament, using the missions board and game rules they created, or by following the game rules listed below.
Sample Game Rules:
Objective of offending team: Maneuver the energy disk to the hanger (scoring)
Objective of defending team: Prevent offending team from retrieving energy disk.
Each team only has one Ozobot to program. Offending and defending teams both load their respective programs onto their Ozobot.
Energy disk is placed in the center of the mission board (halfway between the start and hanger).
Offending team starts at the “Start,” defending team starts anywhere in between the hanger and the center of the board.
Offending team has 30 seconds for their energy disk to reach the goal. During this time, the defending team will attempt to defend their hanger.
Judge (typically the teacher or a neutral student) will award or take away points from both teams. See “Points” for instructions.
Teams will then switch, and repeat steps 1 – 3.
Points:
Offending team points:
+5 points for getting their energy disk in the hanger
-1 point each time they cross a line on the board
-2 points for going off the mission board
Defending team points:
+5 points for successfully preventing the offending team from scoring
-2 points for going off the mission board

One Ozobot per three or four students
Mission boards (three would be sufficient); this could be large whiteboards, cardboard, and the like. Construction paper works too.
Ozobot Blocky programming software installed
3D printer
3D modeling software, such as Tinkercad or Sketchup
8 – 9 hours
Students should have a basic knowledge of 3D design, and 3D design for 3D printing. Students should also have a beginner’s coding experience with Ozobot and Blockly.

Students will have created and designed a game, mission board, and have competed in that game by programming their Ozobot and 3D design/printed appendages to their Ozobot. Grading will be based on how well each team worked together, sportsmanship, as well as how many points were awarded to each team (see Game Rules description for points). Mission Board Example

title: YAFSH - Yet another filament spool holder.

description.text:
Yep, it's another one.  
I didn't try to look for derivatives, I'm sure there are similar spool holders.  I measured as many spools as I could get my hands on, and this taper is carefully chosen to ensure that it fits all those spools.  No guarantee that this will fit your spool.  Requires 2 608 bearings, designed to be used with M8 or 5/16th inch threaded rod.

author: FangDoc59

description.text:
A system for blackboard/bulletin/white board physics demonstrations.

Created because the only similar item available costs over $1000. I will be developing this over the summer to incorporate as much standard physics lab equipment as possible. Being able to do certain demonstrations on the board is invaluable. With a pendulum you can mark the position of the max amplitude and have students simple measure the change in height and the amplitude. Projectile motion is nice because you can have students guess and draw the path of the projectile. I will see if I can get a photogate up there and maybe involve other vernier sensors.

Demonstrations included so far:
Balancing Lever
Pendulum
K'nex Pulley
K'nex Gears
Ramps for projectile motion (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1357028)

Still to come:

  • Suction cup options (Need a very strong magnet to handle any demonstrations with weights - suction cups on a whiteboard or smartboard would hold up better). I will build off of 'suction cup shelf' to create flat ramps etc (as well as chalk/pushpin organizers)
  • Physical Vectors that can be moved around and possibly scaled.
  • General improvements to the design

Suggestions are more than welcomed.

1/2" magnets BTW.
This project can used throughout a physics course for various demonstrations entirely on a blackboard or magnetic dry erase board.
Most lessons can be completed in a standard 40 minute period.
These require some K-nex pieces (pulleys and gears). Glue magnets in place.

Any physics textbook.
Phet Simulations (https://phet.colorado.edu/en/simulations/category/new)
Standard physics assessments (Quizzes/tests)
Phet simulation website has some handouts based on topic.

Objectives

Students learn...
Projectile Motion
Newton's Laws
Gear ratios
Pendulum period and frequency
Balancing Torques

Audiences

5-12 physics students.

Skills Learned

Vector Addition
Newton's Laws
Balancing Torque
Period/Frequency of a pendulum.

comments.text: My colleague bought an inexpensive (relatively speaking) marble chute system.  it inspired us to try to make similar setups using our FFCrePros. Using onShape links could be created to design files as well as the .stl where it is relatively straightforward to make gears and pulleys as well.  Useful additional parts is to take PVC pipe and section it lengthwise as we did for a kinetic sculpture (good for straight runs).  1cm NdFeB magnets are cheap these days and can be bought in bulk. The suggestion of putting a thin rubber backing on the contact point will also help as will a return field (though putting a hole through the magnet increases the cost). Theraband or some other similar material used by personal trainers (your PhysEd pholks may even have a little lying around) may serve well here.  Great work!
comments.author: PBeeken

comments.text: Thank you for your hard work and inspiration. I will try these out in my classroom. If i remember to get back here, I'll drop some feedback
comments.author: MSharkey

comments.text: I wouldn't try this out yet. The idea is great but I haven't had the time to finalize the designs. Magnets need to be much stronger and new pieces need to be developed.
comments.author: MSharkey

comments.text:
First, cool idea!
Just an comment regarding the magnets - use magnets with the steel return cup (it nearly doubles the attractive force), such as these:
https://www.kjmagnetics.com/products.asp?cat=175
Also, if slipping is still a problem, consider using a thin layer of rubber between the magnet and the board to increase the coefficient of friction, or get some of these rubber coated magnets:
https://www.kjmagnetics.com/products.asp?cat=6
